newsitem.title: UK: Boots makes 400 mln stg payout.
newsitem.headline: Boots makes 400 mln stg payout.

text.p: British retailer and pharmacist Boots Co Plc said on Thursday it would hand 400.5 million pounds ($653.7 million) back to shareholders via a special dividend of 44.2 pence a share.

The payout was announced along with an 8.7 percent increase in annual profits before tax and exceptional items to 536.2 million pounds. Cash-rich Boots said the special dividend was in line with the group's stated policy of delivering shareholder value.

The retailer, also owner of car accessory chain Halfords and home DIY chain Do It All, has handed money back to shareholders on two other occasions via share buybacks; 511 million pounds in 1994 and 300 million in June last year.
The company said it had given shareholders a total of 1.7 billion pounds over the last three years in dividends, buybacks and tax credits.
The special payout, which has clearance from the UK tax authorities, carries a tax credit of 11.05 pence, or 100.1 million pounds in total.
Paying surplus cash to shareholders has become fashionable over the past few years. Last week, music giant EMI Plc and Thorn Plc between them promised investors nearly 600 million pounds.
But special dividends have become a more attractive route than share buybacks after changes to tax rules on such schemes last autumn.
Retail analysts had speculated Boots might propose a special dividend this month ahead of the Labour government's first budget in July, which could change the rules again.
The special dividend will be payable on June 13. After the payout Boots' will have pro forma gearing as of March 31 1997 of 10.5 percent.

Boots The Chemist, the group's main business, increased sales on a comparable store basis by 4.7 percent last year. Operating profits before exceptional items rose to 426.5 million pounds from 384.8 million.
Boots also announced plans to go ahead with its Advantage "smart" loyalty card, after regional trials, but gave no details on the timing or scope of the launch.
